content.description: This climb leads up a series of increasingly wide cracks to the very top notch in Eagle Rock. This route has a bit of everything, and the pro takes a bit of thought at places! The rock is crumbly in many places, but with a bit of traffic this could be one of the best 9's in the city.
content.protection: Gear to 4. Bring some double runner.
content.location: Main face of eagle rock. These cracks are visible almost immediately from the first viewpoint on the trail out.

content.description:
The obvious line of bolts up the cool green licheny face.

A great face climb in cool position. The crux comes at  the second or third bolt (sorry it was a couple months ago) and involves some hard crimping with not much for feet. Then solid 5.10 face climbing to a casual finish at a two bolt anchor.

The anchor needs a little help. Chains would be good, there was a lot of tat up there.
content.protection: Bring gear for the initial horizontal, medium cams will suffice, then 6 (or was it 7?) bolts to a two bolt anchor.

content.description:
A profound and aesthetic, single pitch crack with a few tricky moves. Great jams, good gear, and length to boot!

Climb an overlap to a two inch crack in a shallow dihedral. Follow the break heading into an alcove and pull a small roof. Protect and pass the thin and inobvious crux, then continue on another 65 feet using the crack to finish at a chain anchor tucked away to the left just before the top of the butress.
content.protection: Slings, stopper, and cams to 4 inches. A 70 meter rope is strongly advised to avoid down climbing.
content.location:
Directly left of the bolted

Fly Like an Eagle

, this is the left most, thinnest and longest crack line.
